title: Vibrant Fashion Photography: Color Theory, Lighting & Workflow
summary: Fashion photographer Lindsay Adler demonstrates a complete workflow for a high-contrast, colorful fashion shoot. The tutorial covers selecting a color harmony, calibrating equipment, building a multi-light setup with gels and continuous lighting, using shutter drag techniques, and final color grading.

steps.action: Select a color harmony based on the wardrobe using an interactive color wheel.
Calibrate monitors to ensure color accuracy across different displays.
Photograph a color chart to set white balance and verify exposure detail in whites and blacks.
Set up the key light (neutral white) to carve out facial features.
Add a second light with a magenta gel to create an analogous color scheme on the background.
steps.tool: Strip Softbox with Grid + Magenta Gel

steps.action: Add a hair light with a yellow/orange gel to create the split complementary contrast.
steps.tool: Strip Softbox with Grid + Yellow Gel

steps.action: Introduce a continuous blue light source for creative effects.
Use the 'Dragging the Shutter' technique (1/10th sec) to register the continuous light and create motion blur.
Turn off modeling lights on strobes to prevent unwanted ambient light contamination during the long exposure.
Perform color grading (contrast, exposure, saturation) on the tethered capture.
Add atmospheric effects to create bloom and texture.
steps.tool: Black Pro Mist Filter & Atmosphere Aerosol

key_takeaways: Start with a deliberate color harmony (e.g., split complementary) to guide lighting and styling choices.
Color management tools like calibrators and color checkers are essential for accurate results.
To mix strobes with continuous light, slow down the shutter speed (drag the shutter) to let the continuous light register.
Build lighting setups one light at a time to understand the contribution of each source.
Atmospheric tools like haze and diffusion filters add depth and 'bloom' to highlights.
